URL.summary: The URL interface is used to parse, construct, normalize, and encode URL. It works by providing properties which allow you to easily read and modify the components of a URL.

remarks.para: You normally create a new URL object by specifying the URL as a string when calling its constructor, or by providing a relative URL and a base URL. You can then easily read the parsed components of the URL or make changes to the URL.

-Polyfill of URL in core-js
-URL API
-What is a URL?
-.

URLCanParse.summary: The URL.canParse() static method of the interface returns a boolean indicating whether or not an absolute URL, or a relative URL combined with a base URL, are parsable and valid.

remarks.para:
This is a fast and easy alternative to constructing a URL within a try...catch block.
It returns true for the same values for which the URL() constructor would succeed, and false for the values that would cause the constructor to throw.

-
-A polyfill of URL.canParse() is available in core-js

URLCanParse.returns: true if the URL can be parsed and is valid; false otherwise.

URLCreateObjectURL.summary:
The createObjectURL() static method of the interface
creates a string containing a blob URL pointing to the object given in the parameter.

remarks.para: For more information, see blob URLs.
To release an object URL, call .

blockquote.para:
This feature is not available in Service Workers due to its
potential to create memory leaks.

remarks.para:
-Blob URLs
-Using files from web applications
-Using object URLs to display images
-
-
-

URLCreateObjectURL.returns:
A string containing an object URL that can be used to reference the
contents of the specified source object.

URLHash.summary: The hash property of the interface is a string containing a "#" followed by the fragment identifier of the URL. If the URL does not have a fragment identifier, this property contains an empty string, "".

remarks.para: This property can be set to change the fragment identifier of the URL. When setting, a single "#" prefix is added to the provided value, if not already present. Setting it to "" removes the fragment identifier.
The fragment is Percent-encoding when setting but not percent-decoded when reading.
-The interface it belongs to.

URLHost.summary: The host property of the interface is a string containing the host, which is the , and then, if the {{glossary("port")}} of the URL is nonempty, a ":", followed by the of the URL. If the URL does not have a hostname, this property contains an empty string, "".

remarks.para: This property can be set to change both the hostname and the port of the URL. If the URL's scheme is not hierarchical (which the URL standard calls "special schemes"), then it has no concept of a host and setting this property has no effect.

blockquote.para: If the given value for the host setter lacks a port, the URL's port will not change. This can be unexpected as the host getter does return a URL-port string, so one might have assumed the setter to always "reset" both.

remarks.para: -The interface it belongs to.

URLHostname.summary: The hostname property of the interface is a string containing either the {{glossary("domain name")}} or {{glossary("IP address")}} of the URL. If the URL does not have a hostname, this property contains an empty string, "". IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are normalized, such as stripping leading zeros, and domain names are converted to IDN.

remarks.para: This property can be set to change the hostname of the URL. If the URL's scheme is not hierarchical (which the URL standard calls "special schemes"), then it has no concept of a host and setting this property has no effect.
-The interface it belongs to.

URLHref.summary:
The href property of the interface is
a string containing the whole URL.

remarks.para: -The interface it belongs to.

URLOrigin.summary: The origin read-only property of the interface returns a string containing the Unicode serialization of the origin of the represented URL.

remarks.para: The exact structure varies depending on the type of URL:
For all other cases, the string "null" is returned.

-The interface
-origin glossary term

URLParse.summary: The URL.parse() static method of the interface returns a newly created object representing the URL defined by the parameters.

remarks.para:
If the given base URL or the resulting URL are not parsable and valid URLs, null is returned.
This is an alternative to using the constructor to construct a URL within a try...catch block, or using to check the parameters and returning null if the method returns false.

-URL() constructor, which throws if the passed parameters define an invalid URL
-A polyfill of URL.parse() is available in core-js

URLParse.returns: A URL if the parameters can be resolved to a valid URL; null otherwise.

URLPassword.summary: The password property of the interface is a string containing the password component of the URL. If the URL does not have a password, this property contains an empty string, "".

remarks.para: This property can be set to change the password of the URL. If the URL has no or its scheme is file:, then setting this property has no effect.
The password is Percent-encoding when setting but not percent-decoded when reading.
-The interface it belongs to.

URLPathname.summary: The pathname property of the interface represents a location in a hierarchical structure. It is a string constructed from a list of path segments, each of which is prefixed by a / character.

remarks.para:
HTTPS, HTTP, or other URLs with hierarchical schemes (which the URL standard calls "special schemes") always have at least one (invisible) path segment: the empty string.
The pathname value for such URLs will therefore always have at least one / character.

For non-hierarchical schemes, the pathname is known as an opaque path (meaning, the URL parser does not try to split it into a list of segments). In this case, an empty path results in the pathname property being the empty string. Trailing spaces in opaque paths are stripped during initial parsing if the hash and search are both empty; otherwise, they are percent-encoded as %20 even when hash and search are later set to empty strings.

blockquote.para: Percent-encoding trailing spaces in opaque paths is not widely implemented. Some browsers implement the old behavior of stripping trailing spaces from pathname whenever the hash and search properties are both empty strings. In these browsers, setting hash or search may change the pathname as well. In even older browsers, the trailing space remains after removing hash and search, causing serialization and parsing to not round-trip.

remarks.para: -The interface it belongs to.

URLPort.summary: The port property of the interface is a string containing the port number of the URL. If the port is the default for the protocol (80 for ws: and http:, 443 for wss: and https:, and 21 for ftp:), this property contains an empty string, "".

remarks.para: This property can be set to change the port of the URL. If the URL has no or its scheme is file:, then setting this property has no effect. It also silently ignores invalid port numbers.
-The interface it belongs to.

URLProtocol.summary: The protocol property of the interface is a string containing the protocol or scheme of the URL, including the final ":".

remarks.para: This property can be set to change the protocol of the URL. A ":" is appended to the provided string if not provided. The provided scheme has to be compatible with the rest of the URL to be considered valid.
-The interface it belongs to.

URLRevokeObjectURL.summary:
The revokeObjectURL() static method of the interface
releases an existing object URL which was previously created by calling
.

remarks.para: For more information, see blob URLs.

Call this method when you've finished
using an object URL to let the browser know not to keep the reference to the file any
longer.
If the objectURL argument passed is not a currently-active object URL — for example if it is an invalid URL, non-object URL, or is already revoked — then calling this method does nothing.

blockquote.para:
This method is not available in Service Workers, due to
issues with the interface's life cycle and the potential for leaks.

remarks.para:
-Blob URLs
-Using files from web applications
-Using object URLs to display images
-

URLSearch.summary: The search property of the interface is a search string, also called a query string, that is a string containing a "?" followed by the parameters of the URL. If the URL does not have a search query, this property contains an empty string, "".

remarks.para: This property can be set to change the query string of the URL. When setting, a single "?" prefix is added to the provided value, if not already present. Setting it to "" removes the query string.
The query is Percent-encoding when setting but not percent-decoded when reading.

Modern browsers provide the property to make it easy to
parse out the parameters from the query string.
-The interface it belongs to.

URLSearchParams.summary:
The searchParams read-only property of the
interface returns a object allowing
access to the GET decoded query arguments contained in the URL.

URLToJSON.summary:
The toJSON() method of the interface
returns a string containing a serialized version of the URL,
although in practice it seems to have the same effect as
.

remarks.para: -Polyfill of URL.prototype.toJSON in core-js

URLToString.summary:
The toString() method of the interface returns a
string containing the whole URL. It is effectively a read-only version
of .

remarks.para: -The interface it belongs to.

URLURL.summary: The URL() constructor returns a newly created object representing the URL defined by the parameters.

remarks.para: If the given base URL or the resulting URL are not valid URLs, the JavaScript exception is thrown.

-, a non-throwing alternative to this constructor
-Polyfill of URL in core-js
-The interface it belongs to: .

URLUsername.summary: The username property of the interface is a string containing the username component of the URL. If the URL does not have a username, this property contains an empty string, "".

remarks.para: This property can be set to change the username of the URL. If the URL has no or its scheme is file:, then setting this property has no effect.
The username is Percent-encoding when setting but not percent-decoded when reading.
-The interface it belongs to.
